fields.answer: Elimination of micro-organisms and toxins from the root canal system in order to create an environment which promotes healing of the periradicular tissues so that the tooth may be retained as a functional member of the dentition.
fields.question: What is the purpose of root canal treatment?

fields.answer: Caries. Trauma. Severe periodontal disease. Cracks/fractures.
fields.question: Give 4 examples of things which may lead to periradicular disease.

fields.answer: Enterococcus Faecalis
fields.question: Give an example of a prominent faculative anaerobe responsible for pulpal necrosis.

fields.answer: Shaping, irrigation & 3D obturation.
fields.question: State 3 things key to endodontic success.

fields.answer: Long cone paralleling periapical.
fields.question: Which type of radiograph should be taken pre-operatively?

fields.answer: Minimal apical curvature. 23mm.
fields.question: Describe the general root morphology of an upper central incisor. What is their average length?

fields.answer: 1 canal inclined palatally with distal apical curvature. 21-22mm.
fields.question: Describe the general root morphology of an upper lateral incisor. what is their average length?

fields.answer: 26.5mm. Distal and labial curvature, narrow apex.
fields.question: What is the average length of a maxillary canine? Describe its' apex.
What percentage of lower incisors have 2 canals? What is the average length of lower incisors?
What percentage of mandibular canines have 2 canals? What is the average length of a mandibular canine?
How many root canals are usually present in an upper molar?

fields.answer: a bifurcation of the root canal.
fields.question: What could be present clinically, if radiographically the root canal moves from clear to faded?

fields.answer: Endodontic explorer (DG 16 probe). Removing calcified deposits and pulp stones.
fields.question: Which probe is used to locate and explore root canals? Other than locating canals, what are the functions that the DG 16 probe performs? (2)

fields.answer: (a) Triangular (b) Ovoid.
fields.question: What shape should the access cavity be in; (a) Incisors (b) Canines?

fields.answer: Gross caries, advanced periodontal disease, trauma resulting in pulpal necrosis, periapical infections.
fields.question: Give 4 indications that a tooth may require extraction.

fields.answer: Lower forceps have a 90 degree bend in them.
fields.question: How do you differentiate between upper and lower forceps?

fields.answer: Upper premolar forceps are curved, anterior forceps are straight.
fields.question: How would you differentiate between upper straight forceps and upper universal forceps?

fields.answer: The have a "beak" on one side of the forcep to engage furcations.
fields.question: What is unique about upper molar forceps?

fields.answer: The furcation between the mesiobuccal and distobuccal roots.
fields.question: Which furcation is engaged by the "beak" on upper molar forceps?

fields.answer: The points of the forceps engage the furcation region, lift the tooth and therefore increase mobility of the tooth.
fields.question: What is the purpose of "cowhorn" forceps?

fields.answer: all single rooted lower teeth. (incisors, canines, premolars.)
fields.question: Which teeth are lower "universal" forceps used on?

fields.answer: Couplands, cryers and warwick james.
fields.question: Name 3 types of elevators.

fields.answer:
Wedging between alveolar bone and tooth to increase mobility.
they can be used to lift retained roots/root fragments from their sockets.
fields.question: What are couplands elevators used for?

fields.answer:
Hypercementosis.
Ankylosis.
Abnormal root no.
Abnormal root morphology.
Thick cortical bone.
fields.question: Give 4 possible cause of increased resistance in a tooth being extracted.

fields.answer:
You may hear a large "crunching" sound on fracture.
Mobility of the alveolus/teeth in the tuberosity area.
Tear in the palatal mucosa.
fields.question: How would a fractured maxillary tuberosity present?

fields.answer: A Prosthetic appliance permanently attached to teeth, which replaces one or more missing teeth.
fields.question: Define a "bridge.

fields.answer:
Soft tissue/gingivae & alveolar bone.
A denture.
fields.question:
Which areas of dental hard/soft tissue do bridges fail to reproduce? (2) 
What is the only dental prosthesis capable of reproducing these areas?

fields.answer: Aesthetics, function, speech and maintenance of dental health.
fields.question: State 4 reasons why a clinician may choose to address tooth loss.

fields.answer: Partial denture, orthodontic space closure or an implant retained/supported prosthesis.
fields.question: Other than a bridge, state 3 potential treatment options for the restoration of an edentulous space.

fields.answer:
General - function/stability, appearance & speech.
Local - large teeth, heavily restored teeth & a favourable occlusion.
fields.question: State 3 General and 3 Local indications for placing bridgework.

fields.answer:
General - poor oral hygiene, periodontal disease, teeth with large pulps.
Local - length of span is too great, insufficent root surface area for support, insufficient remaining tooth tissue.
fields.question: State 3 General and 3 Local contraindications for placing bridgework.

fields.answer: Bridges increase the load on abutment teeth, therefore, abutment teeth must be healthy and free from disease in order to support the bridge. A tooth with reduced periodontal support would provide compromised and insufficient support for a bridge.
fields.question: Why is the presence of periodontal disease considered a contraindication of bridgework?

fields.answer:
(a) A tooth which serves as an attachment for a bridge.
(b) An artificial tooth which is suspended from an abutment.
fields.question: Define the following terms; (a) abutment. (b) pontic.

fields.answer: Extra or intracoronal restorations which are connected to the pontic and cemented to the abutment tooth.
fields.question: What are "retainers", with regards to bridge design?

fields.answer: The "saddle".
fields.question: What is the name given to he edentulous area over which the pontic will lie?

fields.answer: Either a retainer or a pontic. For example, an adhesive cantilever bridge which has a retainer on tooth 13 and is restoring the saddle area of 12 could be described as a 2 unit bridge.
fields.question: What is a bridge "unit"?

fields.answer: 3 units.
fields.question: How many units are present in a bridge with 2 retainers and 1 pontic?

fields.answer: An abutment tooth which stands between and is supporting 2 pontics, each pontic is attached to another retainer.
fields.question: What is a "pier" in bridge design?

fields.answer: A bridge which has a rigid retainer at each end of the pontic.
fields.question: Describe a fixed-fixed bridge.

fields.answer: A fixed moveable has one rigid connector and one moveable connector. Typically the moveable portion of the bridge will be present in the mesial portion of the restoration and the rigid will be distal.
fields.question: What is the difference between a fixed-fixed and fixed-moveable bridge?

fields.answer: A bridge with only one retainer. Distal.
fields.question: What is a cantilever bridge? Typically, which side is the retainer preferably positioned?

fields.answer: A "Hybrid Bridge".
fields.question: Which style of bridge uses one conventionally prepared abutment and one resin retainer preparation?

fields.answer: One pontic is attached to a metal arm which runs along the palate to connect to a retainer on a posterior tooth.
fields.question: Describe the historic "Spring Cantilever".

fields.answer:
Advantages - max. strength/support, useful in long spans, simpler lab construction.
Disadvantages - Difficult preparations, destructive of tooth tissue, abutments require a common path of insertion.
fields.question: Give 3 advantages and disadvantages to a fixed-fixed bridge.

fields.answer:
Advantages - preparations don't require a common path of insertion, preparations are independently retentive, preparations can be more conservative.
Disadvantages - length of span is limited, complex lab work, difficult to provisionalise.
fields.question: Give 3 advantages and  disadvantages of a fixed-moveable bridge.

fields.answer:
Advantages - conservative design, no need for a parallel.
Disadvantages - short span only, very rigid.
fields.question: State 2 advantages & disadvantages of cantilever bridges.

fields.answer:
Advantage - useful if adjacent teeth are unrestored.
Disadvantage - difficult to clean beneath palatal connector.
fields.question: Give 1 advantage and disadvantage of spring cantilever.

fields.answer:
Abutments must be able to withstand forces previously directed to missing teeth.
Abutments must be free of any disease.
fields.question: State 2 requirements of abutment teeth with regards to supporting pontics.
What is the; (a)optimum (b) minimum crown:root ratio for abutment teeth?
